label: q_ed04_q08_counterfactual
content:
{
  "question_id": "ed04_q08_counterfactual",
  "scope_id": "environmental_drift_04",
  "checkpoint_after": 25,
  "question_type": "counterfactual",
  "prompt": "If agricultural runoff were causing the elevated chromium readings, what spatial pattern would you expect across monitoring stations? Does that match the data?",
  "ground_truth": {
    "canonical_answer": "Agricultural runoff would produce diffuse contamination across multiple stations with gradual onset correlated with rainfall and growing season. Instead, the data shows a sharp point-source pattern \u2014 upstream stations are clean, WQ-03 shows peak concentration, and downstream stations show progressive dilution. Agricultural activity explains turbidity spikes but not the chromium gradient.",
    "required_evidence_refs": [
      "environmental_drift_04_ep_015",
      "environmental_drift_04_ep_016",
      "environmental_drift_04_ep_011"
    ],
    "key_facts": [
      "seasonal nutrient loading explains turbidity spikes but not hexavalent metal signature",
      "progressive chromium concentration decay from peak station to downstream sites indicates single-source contamination",
      "stations upstream of the anomaly source maintain background-level trace metal readings throughout the study",
      "chromium concentrations at the peak monitoring station increased progressively across successive sampling periods, inconsistent with episodic contamination events"
    ]
  }
}
